contentrichtext.text: {{Ref improve|date=October 2011}} <!-- This article was [originally] auto-generated by [[User:Polbot]]. --> {{taxobox |image = Quercus prinoides leaves.jpg |caption = The leaves of ''Q. prinoides'' (center) resemble those of ''Q. prinus''. |status = LR/lc |status_system = iucn2.3 |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Fagaceae]] |genus = ''[[Quercus]]'' |species = '''''Q. prinoides''''' |binomial = ''Quercus prinoides'' |binomial_authority = [[Carl Ludwig von Willdenow|Willd.]] |}} '''''Quercus prinoides''''', commonly known as '''Dwarf Chinkapin Oak''', '''Dwarf Chinquapin Oak''', '''Dwarf Chestnut Oak''' or '''Scrub Chestnut Oak''', is a shrubby, [[cloning|clone-forming]] [[Quercus|oak]] native to eastern [[North America]], ranging from [[Massachusetts]] to the [[Carolinian forest]] zone of [[southern Ontario]] to [[Minnesota]], south to [[North Carolina]] and [[Oklahoma]]. ==Classification and nomenclature== ''Quercus prinoides'' was named and described by the German botanist [[Carl Ludwig Willdenow|Karl (Carl) Ludwig Willdenow]] in 1801,<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides">{{cite web|title=Quercus prinoides|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501075|work=Flora of North America|accessdate=8 October 2011}}</ref> in a German journal article by the German-American Pennsylvania botanist [[Gotthilf Heinrich Ernst Muhlenberg]], with the epithet ''prinoides'' referring to its resemblance to [[Quercus prinus|''Quercus prinus'', the chestnut oak]]. However, this shrubby oak, now generally accepted as a distinct species, is more closely related to [[Quercus muehlenbergii|chinkapin oak (''Quercus muhlenbergii'')]] than to chestnut oak.<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides" /> These two kinds of oak have sometimes been considered to be [[conspecific]] (belonging to the same species), in which case the earlier-published name ''Q. prinoides'' has priority, with the larger chinkapin oak then usually classified as ''Quercus prinoides'' var. ''acuminata'', and the shrubby form as ''Q. prinoides'' var. ''prinoides''. ==Description== The dwarf chinkapin oak is a large, clonally spreading [[deciduous]] shrub or very small tree that typically only grows to 13-20 feet (4-6 m) tall and 13-20 feet (4-6 m) wide.<ref>Hightshoe, G.L. (1988). Native Trees, Shrubs, and Vines for Urban and Rural America. New York: Van Nostrand Reinhold.</ref> The leaves of dwarf chinkapin oak closely resemble those of chinkapin oak, although they are smaller: 2-6 in (5-15 cm) long, compared to 4-7 in (10-18 cm) long for chinkapin oak. The acorns are 1/2 to 1 in (15-25 mm) long, with the cup enclosing about half of the acorn.{{fact|date=October 2011}} While similar in foliage and fruits, but with smaller leaves, the dwarf chinkapin oak may also be distinguished from the chinkapin oak by differences in growth habit (the clonally spreading shrubby growth form and smaller proportions of dwarf chinkapin oak, even when grown on rich soils) and habitat (the chinkapin oak is typically found on rocky, [[calcareous]] sites, while the dwarf chinkapin oak is more typically found on dry, often [[soil pH|acidic]], sandy soils or dry shales).<ref Name="FNA Qprinoides" /> ==Ecology and uses== {{expand section|date=October 2011}} The acorns of dwarf chinkapin are sweet tasting and relished by humans and many kinds of wildlife. The wood has little commercial value because of the shrub's small size. ==References== {{reflist}} ==Additional references== * Sternberg, G. 1998. [http://www.iucnredlist.org/search/details.php/33897/all ''Quercus prinoides'']. [http://www.iucnredlist.org 2006 IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. ] Downloaded on 23 August 2007. [[Category:Quercus|prinoides]] [[Category:Least concern plants]] [[Category:Trees of Kansas]] [[Category:Trees of Ontario]] [[Category:Trees of West Virginia]] [[Category:Trees of Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Trees of Delaware]] {{Fagales-stub}}
